--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> I have defined 2 dialects, although they share some
> structure -  a 
> 'neat-run-config' that can be used to initialise a
> neat run, and a 
> 'neat-run-output' that represents the output from a
> run. 

This is probably a good idea...to have an XML format
for loading parameters (we're not doing this
currently).

Our parameters file has grown quite a bit.  I don't
know if your examples were meant to be comprehensive,
but obviously there's stuff like the compatibility
coefficients and speciation compatibility threshold
values.

We make a distinction between the domain (Tic-Tac-Toe)
and the fitness function (direct evolution against
random players, round-robin coevolution, etc.).  And
then for game domains there are all sorts of
additional parameters (win/loss/tie value, etc.).

Some other specific comments:

>    <end-condition>
>          <!-- optional end conditions. If more than
> one specified then 
> terminate on whichever is true first -->

Yeah...this is a good idea.

>       <!-- keep track of innov num in case we wish
> to restart the run? -->
>       <max-innovation-id>12345</max-innovation-id>
>    </neat-run-info>

Yes...we're currently working on loading a population
from file.  This is a good idea.

>    <generation id="1">
>       <generation-info>
>          <save-time>"2004-02-24
> 00:00:12"</save-time>
>          <max-fitness>234</max-fitness>
>          <min-fitness>123</min-fitness>
>          <avg-fitness>222</avg-fitness>
>          <species-count>5</species-count>
>       </generation-info>

Having a species-count tag in generation info is a bit
redundant, but not terribly.

> <connection id="4" src="0" tgt="3" 
> weight="-1.3731676929130425" enabled="1"
> innov-id="12"/>

Why have an "id" and an "innovation-id"?  They should
be the same thing.

Other than that, it definitely looks like a good start
for XML for loading parameters and reviewing stats
during and after a run.  

As I put in my previous mail, we currently use two
types of XML to represent individuals: chromosome.xml
and network.xml, basically mapping to the genotype and
phenotype respectively.  I think this dichotomy is a
good idea, especially as indirect encoding is used. 
In such cases, there will not be a one-to-one mapping
of genotype to phenotype...agreed?

Thus, there's no real need to represent recurrent
connections in genotype XML...likewise, there's no
reason to represent disabled genes in phenotype XML.  

Derek
